entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype+%5C%26+Ship%5C%3A+trigger%5C-scope%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Yoav+Weiss+%5C%28%40Shopify%5C%29%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Yoav Weiss (@Shopify)</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251210" rel="nofollow">Wed, 10 Dec 2025 22:32:18 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>LGTM1
On Wednesday, December 10, 2025 at 8:02:23 PM UTC+1 Bramus Van Damme wrote:</pre><pre>
On Wednesday, December 10, 2025 at 5:09:57 PM UTC+1 Rick Byers wrote:
Hey David, This seems fairly straightforward to me, but I imagine there's probably some developer signals here, right? Somebody who has said why they want this?
Hi, it’s me! :)
This is needed when applying scroll-triggered animations that use selectors which match multiple elements. Without trigger-scope, the last element that declares the trigger would “win”, thereby breaking all other matched element that use the same name for its trigger. With trigger-scope, the name can be contained to a specific subtree, allowing name reuse.
See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3">https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3</a> (Canary with flags) for an example: each image animates individually, each with their own trigger-timeline named --t. Without timeline-trigger scope, all images would animate using the timeline-trigger of the very last element – which is not what you want.
tl;dr Without trigger-scope, it would be near impossible for authors to properly implement scroll-triggered animations.
I'm hearing similar arguments from devs inside of Shopify.
Thanks, Rick
On Tue, Dec 9, 2025 at 4:40 PM David Awogbemila <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0564726a62672b2b2b45666d776a686c70682b6a7762">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6e0f1901090c4040402e09010109020b400d0103">[email protected]</a>
*Explainer* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-</a> animations/blob/main/TRIGGER_SCOPE.md
*Specification* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope</a>
*Summary* trigger-scope gives authors the ability to limit the names of animation triggers declared by trigger-instantiating properties. Trigger-Instantiating properties, such as timeline-trigger, declare names which can be referenced by the animation-trigger property in order to attach animations to triggers. However, these names are global by default (similar to anchor-name) and it is often useful for author to limit the visibility of the names so as to isolate animation-to-trigger interactions.
*Blink component* Blink>Animation <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EAnimation%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EAnimation%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* Missing feature
*Motivation* Similar to anchor-scope[1], trigger-instantiating properties need a mechanism for limiting the visibility of the names declared by the trigger-instantiating property. [1] <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/">https://drafts.csswg.org/</a> css-anchor-position-1/#anchor-scope
*Initial public proposal* *No information provided*
*TAG review* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175</a>
*TAG review status* Pending
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* *No information provided*
*Gecko*: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/</a> issues/1327)
*WebKit*: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/</a> issues/589)
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? *No information provided*
*Debuggability* *No information provided*
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=">https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=</a> trigger-scope (As of this writing, only the parsing tests are present on the dashboard but functional tests[1] are quickly following) [1] <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601</a>
*Flag name on about://flags* *No information provided*
*Finch feature name* *No information provided*
*Non-finch justification* *No information provided*
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/466134208">https://crbug.com/466134208</a>
*Estimated milestones* Shipping on desktop145Shipping on Android145Shipping on WebView145
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). *No information provided*
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5152759609425920?gate=5794840308744192">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5152759609425920?gate=5794840308744192</a>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to deprecate and remove: BMP extension for decoding JPEG/PNG-embedded-in-BMP
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to deprecate and remove: BMP extension for decoding JPEG/PNG-embedded-in-BMP
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+deprecate+and+remove%5C%3A+BMP+extension+for+decoding+JPEG%5C%2FPNG%5C-embedded%5C-in%5C-BMP%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to deprecate and remove: BMP extension for decoding JPEG/PNG-embedded-in-BMP</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251212" rel="nofollow">Fri, 12 Dec 2025 12:23:41 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>LGTM2 - It seems to have ended up on our lists in chromestatus when I </tt><tt>put my LGTM there, but you should also trigger the other reviews (or </tt><tt>make them N/A if you think that is appropriate). Privacy, testing, </tt><tt>enterprise, and so on. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I guess there is a non-zero risk that there is some important </tt><tt>application using this but the risk must be extremely close to zero. I </tt><tt>don't even know of a way to create such files, and quickly searching the </tt><tt>web didn't tell me anything either. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
/Daniel
On 2025-12-12 19:27, Łukasz Anforowicz wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>On Fri, Dec 12, 2025 at 1:34 AM Philip Jägenstedt </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0660696928282846656e74696b6f736b28697461">[email protected]</a>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hmm, I went to approve it in chromestatus as well, but <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a> looks like it's not been updated. Can you update that entry and then resend the email so that entry and emails are properly linked?
</pre><tt>Sorry about that. I went ahead and entered 145 as the shipping </tt><tt>milestone. And I set the Finch feature name. Is there any other </tt><tt>information and/or fields that I should add to the Chrome status entry? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Fri, Dec 12, 2025 at 10:32 AM Philip Jägenstedt <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3650595918181876555e44595b5f435b18594451">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
LGTM1, if it's not supported in Firefox or Safari and we cannot detect any usage via UMA, this is very likely safe from a web compat perspective. As long as it's Finch-controllable we can revert it if serious breakage does surface to give time for migration.
On Thu, Dec 11, 2025 at 7:54 PM Łukasz Anforowicz <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e08c958b81cececea08388928f8d89958dce8f9287">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Hello,
BMP image decoder that ships in Chromium/Blink is capable of decoding JPEG and/or PNG images embedded inside BMP (in addition to the typical RLE or other basic BMP encodings). In <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a>>we propose to remove this BMP extension, tracking this work with <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/456842524">https://crbug.com/456842524</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/456842524">https://crbug.com/456842524</a>>.
Answering the questions from
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations</a>>:
*
Why are we removing this feature?:
o
Security: Since 2019, we've been presented with compelling evidence
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/12/a-deep-dive-into-nso-zero-click.html">https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/12/a-deep-dive-into-nso-zero-click.html</a>>that surprising and rarely-used support for nesting formats is a path to security bugs. Such a possibility is especially worrying for BMP, which is otherwise considered a pretty simple format.
o
Code health: Removing code is expected to improve code health. Additionally, removing this corner-case will simplify migrating
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fc7KI1AhvCOLZhAStg_jIQLlCA3aCZP4vhgFlLn1ZTk/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fc7KI1AhvCOLZhAStg_jIQLlCA3aCZP4vhgFlLn1ZTk/edit?usp=sharing</a>>the BMP decoder to a memory-safe language.
o
Interoperability:
+
Removing this BMP extension will improve interoperability/consistency across browsers, because today only Chrome supports this BMP extension:
#
Manual testing of browser support is possible by visiting
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html">https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html">https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html</a>>and looking at the result of rendering `q/rgb24jpeg.bmp` and `q/rgb24png.bmp`
#
Chrome 141.0.7390.134: rendered okay
*
Support for JPEG/PNG-in-BMP was added
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1777120">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1777120</a>>in 2019, in Chrome 78.0.3899.0
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/8319e7a6dbe63b6ef04c3cfe75f0df1947b00fb0">https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/8319e7a6dbe63b6ef04c3cfe75f0df1947b00fb0</a>>
*
IIUC there was no Blink Intent for this addition + the main motivation was covering all files from the BMP test suite (I note that these 2 test inputs are in a “q” directory which was expanded to “questionable” when adding
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5269009">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5269009</a>>the test inputs to Chromium).
#
Firefox 143.0.4 and 144.0.2: not rendered
#
Safari 18.6: not rendered
+
There is no official spec:
#
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file</a>>says:
*
“No specification; however, Microsoft provides general documentation of the format at
docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage
<<a rel="nofollow" href="http://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage">http://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage</a>>”
*
“Warning: You should typically avoid using BMP files for website content. The most common form of BMP file represents the data as an uncompressed raster image, resulting in large file sizes compared to png or jpg image types. More efficient BMP formats exist but are not widely used, and rarely supported in web browsers.”
*
“Theoretically, several compression algorithms are supported, and the image data can also be stored in JPEG or PNG format within the BMP file.”
#
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures</a>>says:
*
“This [JPEG-and-PNG-in-BMP] extension is not intended as a means to supply general JPEG and PNG decompression to applications, but rather to allow applications to send JPEG- and PNG-compressed images directly to printers having hardware support for JPEG and PNG images.”
*
What is the cost of removing this feature?
o
No usage has been registered via a recently added UMA data: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>
+
UMA data gathered in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>for M143 shows no usage in Canary/Dev, Beta, not Stable release channels (not just minimal usage, but no usage whatsoever)
+
UMA data can have blind spots (users that do not enable UMA), but this seems like an acceptable risk
*
When will the feature be removed?
o
We propose to remove support for this BMP extension in Chrome 145 (which is tentatively scheduled to branch on January 12, 2026, and release to the Stable channel on Feb 10, 2026).
*
What is the suggested alternative?
o
Please use PNG and/or JPEG images **directly** rather than embedding them inside a BMP format.
Other notes:
*
We don’t plan to explicitly coordinate with other web rendering engines, because other browsers do not support this feature.
*
We don’t plan for a deprecation period, because there is no known usage (based on UMA <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>) and explicit warnings (on Mozilla Developer Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file</a>>) advise against using BMP in general, and this BMP extension specifically (calling it only “theoretically supported”)
Best regards,
Lukasz Anforowicz (on behalf of the Chrome Memory Safety and the Skia teams)
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype+%5C%26+Ship%5C%3A+trigger%5C-scope%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype & Ship: trigger-scope</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251215" rel="nofollow">Mon, 15 Dec 2025 06:38:23 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 12/11/25 1:32 a.m., Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1</pre><pre></pre><tt>On Wednesday, December 10, 2025 at 8:02:23 PM UTC+1 Bramus Van Damme </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Wednesday, December 10, 2025 at 5:09:57 PM UTC+1 Rick Byers wrote:
Hey David, This seems fairly straightforward to me, but I imagine there's probably some developer signals here, right? Somebody who has said why they want this?
Hi, it’s me! :)
This is needed when applying scroll-triggered animations that use selectors which match multiple elements. Without trigger-scope, the last element that declares the trigger would “win”, thereby breaking all other matched element that use the same name for its trigger. With trigger-scope, the name can be contained to a specific subtree, allowing name reuse.
See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3">https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3">https://codepen.io/bramus/pen/dPMVoYR/2e5fd8b6a35cc77cfb8faf0f16caf1e3</a>> (Canary with flags) for an example: each image animates individually, each with their own trigger-timeline named --t. Without timeline-trigger scope, all images would animate using the timeline-trigger of the very last element – which is not what you want.
tl;dr Without trigger-scope, it would be near impossible for authors to properly implement scroll-triggered animations.
I'm hearing similar arguments from devs inside of Shopify.
Thanks, Rick
On Tue, Dec 9, 2025 at 4:40 PM David Awogbemila <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="93f2e4fcf4f1bdbdbdd3f0fbe1fcfefae6febdfce1f4">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="19786e767e7b373737597e76767e757c377a7674">[email protected]</a>
*Explainer*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-animations/blob/main/TRIGGER_SCOPE.md">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-animations/blob/main/TRIGGER_SCOPE.md</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-animations/blob/main/TRIGGER_SCOPE.md">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/scroll-triggered-animations/blob/main/TRIGGER_SCOPE.md</a>>
*Specification* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations-2/#trigger-scope</a>>
*Summary* trigger-scope gives authors the ability to limit the names of animation triggers declared by trigger-instantiating properties. Trigger-Instantiating properties, such as timeline-trigger, declare names which can be referenced by the animation-trigger property in order to attach animations to triggers. However, these names are global by default (similar to anchor-name) and it is often useful for author to limit the visibility of the names so as to isolate animation-to-trigger interactions.
*Blink component* Blink>Animation
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EAnimation%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EAnimation%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* Missing feature
*Motivation* Similar to anchor-scope[1], trigger-instantiating properties need a mechanism for limiting the visibility of the names declared by the trigger-instantiating property. [1] <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-anchor-position-1/#anchor-scope">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-anchor-position-1/#anchor-scope</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-anchor-position-1/#anchor-scope">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-anchor-position-1/#anchor-scope</a>>
*Initial public proposal* /No information provided/
*TAG review* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1175</a>>
*TAG review status* Pending
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* /No information provided/
/Gecko/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1327">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1327</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1327">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1327</a>>)
/WebKit/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/589">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/589</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/589">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/589</a>>)
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
/No information provided/
*Debuggability* /No information provided/
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=trigger-scope">https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=trigger-scope</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=trigger-scope">https://wpt.fyi/results/?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=trigger-scope</a>> (As of this writing, only the parsing tests are present on the dashboard but functional tests[1] are quickly following) [1] <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/56601</a>>
*Flag name on about://flags* /No information provided/
*Finch feature name* /No information provided/
*Non-finch justification* /No information provided/
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/466134208">https://crbug.com/466134208</a>
*Estimated milestones* Shipping on desktop145Shipping on Android145Shipping on WebView145
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
/No information provided/
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5152759609425920?gate=5794840308744192">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5152759609425920?gate=5794840308744192</a>

This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.

entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to deprecate and remove: BMP extension for decoding JPEG/PNG-embedded-in-BMP
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+deprecate+and+remove%5C%3A+BMP+extension+for+decoding+JPEG%5C%2FPNG%5C-embedded%5C-in%5C-BMP%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to deprecate and remove: BMP extension for decoding JPEG/PNG-embedded-in-BMP</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251215" rel="nofollow">Mon, 15 Dec 2025 06:41:16 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Can you also request the Enterprise bit? I think they would probably </tt><tt>want this to appear in release notes. Happy to give a third LGTM once </tt><tt>that's done. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 12/12/25 3:23 p.m., Daniel Bratell wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>LGTM2 - It seems to have ended up on our lists in chromestatus when I </tt><tt>put my LGTM there, but you should also trigger the other reviews (or </tt><tt>make them N/A if you think that is appropriate). Privacy, testing, </tt><tt>enterprise, and so on. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I guess there is a non-zero risk that there is some important </tt><tt>application using this but the risk must be extremely close to zero. I </tt><tt>don't even know of a way to create such files, and quickly searching </tt><tt>the web didn't tell me anything either. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-12-12 19:27, Łukasz Anforowicz wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>On Fri, Dec 12, 2025 at 1:34 AM Philip Jägenstedt </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7f1910105151513f1c170d1012160a1251100d18">[email protected]</a>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hmm, I went to approve it in chromestatus as well, but <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a> looks like it's not been updated. Can you update that entry and then resend the email so that entry and emails are properly linked?
</pre><tt>Sorry about that. I went ahead and entered 145 as the shipping </tt><tt>milestone. And I set the Finch feature name. Is there any other </tt><tt>information and/or fields that I should add to the Chrome status entry? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Fri, Dec 12, 2025 at 10:32 AM Philip Jägenstedt <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="88eee7e7a6a6a6c8ebe0fae7e5e1fde5a6e7faef">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
LGTM1, if it's not supported in Firefox or Safari and we cannot detect any usage via UMA, this is very likely safe from a web compat perspective. As long as it's Finch-controllable we can revert it if serious breakage does surface to give time for migration.
On Thu, Dec 11, 2025 at 7:54 PM Łukasz Anforowicz <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b1ddc4dad09f9f9ff1d2d9c3dedcd8c4dc9fdec3d6">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Hello,
BMP image decoder that ships in Chromium/Blink is capable of decoding JPEG and/or PNG images embedded inside BMP (in addition to the typical RLE or other basic BMP encodings). In <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153489630134272</a>>we propose to remove this BMP extension, tracking this work with <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/456842524">https://crbug.com/456842524</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/456842524">https://crbug.com/456842524</a>>.
Answering the questions from
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#feature-deprecations</a>>:
*
Why are we removing this feature?:
o
Security: Since 2019, we've been presented with compelling evidence
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/12/a-deep-dive-into-nso-zero-click.html">https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/12/a-deep-dive-into-nso-zero-click.html</a>>that surprising and rarely-used support for nesting formats is a path to security bugs. Such a possibility is especially worrying for BMP, which is otherwise considered a pretty simple format.
o
Code health: Removing code is expected to improve code health. Additionally, removing this corner-case will simplify migrating
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fc7KI1AhvCOLZhAStg_jIQLlCA3aCZP4vhgFlLn1ZTk/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fc7KI1AhvCOLZhAStg_jIQLlCA3aCZP4vhgFlLn1ZTk/edit?usp=sharing</a>>the BMP decoder to a memory-safe language.
o
Interoperability:
+
Removing this BMP extension will improve interoperability/consistency across browsers, because today only Chrome supports this BMP extension:
#
Manual testing of browser support is possible by visiting
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html">https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html">https://entropymine.com/jason/bmpsuite/bmpsuite/html/bmpsuite.html</a>>and looking at the result of rendering `q/rgb24jpeg.bmp` and `q/rgb24png.bmp`
#
Chrome 141.0.7390.134: rendered okay
*
Support for JPEG/PNG-in-BMP was added
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1777120">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1777120</a>>in 2019, in Chrome 78.0.3899.0
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/8319e7a6dbe63b6ef04c3cfe75f0df1947b00fb0">https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/8319e7a6dbe63b6ef04c3cfe75f0df1947b00fb0</a>>
*
IIUC there was no Blink Intent for this addition + the main motivation was covering all files from the BMP test suite (I note that these 2 test inputs are in a “q” directory which was expanded to “questionable” when adding
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5269009">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5269009</a>>the test inputs to Chromium).
#
Firefox 143.0.4 and 144.0.2: not rendered
#
Safari 18.6: not rendered
+
There is no official spec:
#
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file</a>>says:
*
“No specification; however, Microsoft provides general documentation of the format at
docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage
<<a rel="nofollow" href="http://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage">http://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/gdi/bitmap-storage</a>>”
*
“Warning: You should typically avoid using BMP files for website content. The most common form of BMP file represents the data as an uncompressed raster image, resulting in large file sizes compared to png or jpg image types. More efficient BMP formats exist but are not widely used, and rarely supported in web browsers.”
*
“Theoretically, several compression algorithms are supported, and the image data can also be stored in JPEG or PNG format within the BMP file.”
#
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/gdi/jpeg-and-png-extensions-for-specific-bitmap-functions-and-structures</a>>says:
*
“This [JPEG-and-PNG-in-BMP] extension is not intended as a means to supply general JPEG and PNG decompression to applications, but rather to allow applications to send JPEG- and PNG-compressed images directly to printers having hardware support for JPEG and PNG images.”
*
What is the cost of removing this feature?
o
No usage has been registered via a recently added UMA data: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>
+
UMA data gathered in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>for M143 shows no usage in Canary/Dev, Beta, not Stable release channels (not just minimal usage, but no usage whatsoever)
+
UMA data can have blind spots (users that do not enable UMA), but this seems like an acceptable risk
*
When will the feature be removed?
o
We propose to remove support for this BMP extension in Chrome 145 (which is tentatively scheduled to branch on January 12, 2026, and release to the Stable channel on Feb 10, 2026).
*
What is the suggested alternative?
o
Please use PNG and/or JPEG images **directly** rather than embedding them inside a BMP format.
Other notes:
*
We don’t plan to explicitly coordinate with other web rendering engines, because other browsers do not support this feature.
*
We don’t plan for a deprecation period, because there is no known usage (based on UMA <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/452667935">https://crbug.com/452667935</a>>) and explicit warnings (on Mozilla Developer Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Guides/Formats/Image_types#bmp_bitmap_file</a>>) advise against using BMP in general, and this BMP extension specifically (calling it only “theoretically supported”)
Best regards,
Lukasz Anforowicz (on behalf of the Chrome Memory Safety and the Skia teams)

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Web%5C-Facing+Change+PSA%5C%3A+IndexedDB%5C%3A+SQLite+backend+%5C%28in%5C-memory+contexts%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: IndexedDB: SQLite backend (in-memory contexts)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251215" rel="nofollow">Mon, 15 Dec 2025 06:55:51 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 12/11/25 12:04 p.m., Evan Stade wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>> I assume that the plan is to migrate non-incognito usage to SQLite </tt><tt>as well once we have data on the effect of the migration in the wild. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Correct, the incognito-only launch is an extra precaution to verify </tt><tt>correctness of our implementation in a low-stakes environment. Given </tt><tt>that it doesn't depend on disk i/o, it may or may not provide </tt><tt>particularly useful data in terms of perf or reliability (although we </tt><tt>will collect that information). The extra caution here compared to </tt><tt>other features is due to the risk of data loss --- when a feature </tt><tt>persists data, bugs aren't as easy to correct and implementation </tt><tt>updates can require their own migration. </tt></blockquote><tt>Thanks, that's good to know. And I agree that a temporary "is probably </tt><tt>incognito" signal is fine, assuming temporary is on the order of a year, </tt><tt>not a decade - good luck shipping :). </tt><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>> Among other things, doesn't IndexedDB performance already vary </tt><tt>between incognito and non-incognito sessions due to the in-memory </tt><tt>storage implementation? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>It does, and this likely applies to more than one web API, although </tt><tt>I've never attempted to create an oracle out of this, and it would </tt><tt>probably be pretty flaky since it's also highly dependent on device </tt><tt>specs or system load. Perhaps you could create two IDB databases, and </tt><tt>if the second is created much faster than the first, that's an </tt><tt>indication you're on-the-record/on-disk since the backing store DB </tt><tt>would already be loaded/warmed up for the second creation (with </tt><tt>LevelDB anyway). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
------------------------------------------------------------------------ *From:* Reilly Grant <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4634232f2a68686806252e34292b2f332b68293421">[email protected]</a>> *Sent:* Thursday, December 11, 2025 7:31 AM *To:* Evan Stade <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e58093848b9691cbcbcba5888c86978a968a8391cb868a88">[email protected]</a>> </pre><tt>*Cc:* Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="acc1c5c7c9d8cd828282eccfc4dec3c1c5d9c182c3decb">[email protected]</a>>; <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="85e7e9ecebeea8e1e0f3c5e6edf7eae8ecf0e8abeaf7e2">[email protected]</a> </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="8be9e7e2e5e0a6efeefdcbe8e3f9e4e6e2fee6a5e4f9ec">[email protected]</a>>; <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="33515f5a5d581e52435a1e5c445d5641401e575a40501d1d1d73505b415c5e5a465e1d5c4154">[email protected]</a> </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6f0d03060104420e1f06420018010a1d1c420b061c0c4141412f0c071d0002061a0241001d08">[email protected]</a>>; Abhishek Shanthkumar </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c9a8aba1a0baa1aca2e7baa1a8a7bda1a2bce7e7e789a4a0aabba6baa6afbde7aaa6a4">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>*Subject:* Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: </tt><tt>IndexedDB: SQLite backend (in-memory contexts) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>You don't often get email from <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5725323e3b79797917343f25383a3e223a79382530">[email protected]</a>. Learn why this is </tt><tt>important <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification">https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I assume that the plan is to migrate non-incognito usage to SQLite as </tt><tt>well once we have data on the effect of the migration in the wild. </tt><tt>There are other Incognito oracles so I don't think temporarily adding </tt><tt>a new one is much of a problem. Among other things, doesn't IndexedDB </tt><tt>performance already vary between incognito and non-incognito sessions </tt><tt>due to the in-memory storage implementation? </tt><tt>Reilly Grant | Software Engineer | <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="285a4d4144060606684b405a4745415d4506475a4f">[email protected]</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#4735222e2b69696907242f35282a2e322a69283520">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d1a3b4b8bdffffff91b2b9a3bebcb8a4bcffbea3b6">[email protected]</span></a>> | Google Chrome </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google.com/chrome">https://www.google.com/chrome</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Wed, Dec 10, 2025 at 11:48 AM 'Evan Stade' via blink-dev </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="57353b3e393c7a33322117343f25383a3e223a79382530">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#b9dbd5d0d7d294dddccff9dad1cbd6d4d0ccd497d6cbde">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="86e4eaefe8edabe2e3f0c6e5eef4e9ebeff3eba8e9f4e1">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Here's the demo: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://evanstade.github.io/web-storage-demos/idb-txn-scopes">https://evanstade.github.io/web-storage-demos/idb-txn-scopes</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://evanstade.github.io/web-storage-demos/idb-txn-scopes">https://evanstade.github.io/web-storage-demos/idb-txn-scopes</a>> (it's also linked in the chromestatus.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">http://chromestatus.com/</a>> entry)
Yes, when/if the feature is enabled for just incognito and not on-disk, it would create an incognito detector. However, we want to perform A/B measurements during rollout, so it's not a waterfall rollout, which means it's often not a perfect oracle.
We can close this loophole, but not without drawbacks. We could impose the same behavior on the LevelDB backend in Chromium (for IDB in normal profiles). That would be technically easy to do, and could potentially flush out any breakages in Chromium-only sites before the full SQLite rollout. The problem is that it might have a negative perf impact for LevelDB. (We think that overall SQLite will be as fast or better than LevelDB, but this one detail can potentially reduce parallelization, so in isolation it is a detriment.) And this would impede our ability to fairly compare SQLite and LevelDB performance.
Is the goal to eliminate incognito detection altogether (which seems a little bit on the restrictive side, since there are existing unpatched incognito signals), or just to deteriorate the quality of them, or just to make sure none of them become permanently baked into the platform? To deteriorate reliability of the incognito detection, we could: * hold back 50% of the incognito population indefinitely (which probably still gives us a chance to collect enough metrics/bug reports), or * impose the same transaction behavior on LevelDB some small percent of the time (to minimize perf impact, but make the detector flaky).
The cost in both of these cases is the headache of non-determinism.

On 12/9/25 5:34 p.m., Chromestatus wrote:
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="284d5e49465b5c0606066845414b5a475b474e5c064b4745">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#afcad9cec1dcdb818181efc2c6ccddc0dcc0c9db81ccc0c2">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5c392a3d322f287272721c31353f2e332f333a28723f3331">[email protected]</span></a>>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="58393a30312b303d33762b3039362c30332d7676761835313b2a372b373e2c763b3735">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#93f2f1fbfae0fbf6f8bde0fbf2fde7fbf8e6bdbdbdd3fefaf0e1fce0fcf5e7bdf0fcfe">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bfdeddd7d6ccd7dad491ccd7ded1cbd7d4ca919191ffd2d6dccdd0ccd0d9cb91dcd0d2">[email protected]</span></a>>
*Specification* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB">https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB">https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB</a>>
*Summary* Chromium's IndexedDB implementation is rewritten on top of SQLite, to replace the previous implementation that uses a hybrid of LevelDB and flat files. There is no change to the Web API. This is expected to improve reliability and, to a lesser extent, performance. For now this is applied only to in-memory contexts such as Incognito mode in Chromium and Google Chrome. This limits the impact of any new bugs, as well as puts off the need to worry about migration of existing data persisted to disk.
*Blink component* Blink>Storage>IndexedDB
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EStorage%3EIndexedDB%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EStorage%3EIndexedDB%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* indexeddb <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/indexeddb">https://webstatus.dev/features/indexeddb</a>>
*Search tags* [/features#tags:sqlite]sqlite, [/features#tags:idb]idb, [/features#tags:indexeddb]indexeddb, [/features#tags:leveldb]leveldb
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* Interop: this work entails a web-visible behavioral change concerning an edge case in IDB transaction scheduling. This change brings Chromium in line with Firefox and Safari. (Both new and old behavior are standards-compliant.) See demo. Compatibility: This PSA exists primarily to warn of the risk of unintended breakage. The later step where persisted databases are stored with SQLite, and existing data is migrated to SQLite, will have higher associated risks and will have its own PSA.
Is there a link to a demo? I wonder if this creates a new Incognito mode oracle.
/Gecko/: No signal
/WebKit/: No signal
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
*Security* All data on disk is still segregated by storage bucket (origin). Both new and old implementation are newly fuzz-tested.
*WebView application risks*
/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?/
/No information provided/
*Debuggability* existing IndexedDB DevTools support is unimpacted
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/IndexedDB">https://wpt.fyi/results/IndexedDB</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/IndexedDB">https://wpt.fyi/results/IndexedDB</a>>
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/436880911">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/436880911</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/436880911">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/436880911</a>>

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+WebGPU%5C%3A+%60subgroup_uniformity%60+feature%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: WebGPU: `subgroup_uniformity` feature</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251215" rel="nofollow">Mon, 15 Dec 2025 13:16:27 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">

Blink component Blink>WebGPU
Web Feature ID webgpu
Motivation This feature allows subgroup functionality to be considered uniform in more cases representing better quality-of-life for developers and less likelihood of disabling uniformity checks altogether.
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Approved as a WebGPU language feature at W3C. Meetings include participants from Firefox and Safari.

Web developers: No signals

WebView application risks

Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes All platforms will eventually have support. Will immediately be available on Android, Android WebView, ChromeOS, Mac, and Windows, since those platforms already support WebGPU. WebGPU will also start shipping on Linux in M145 on some devices, so this feature will become available when WebGPU does.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes WebGPU conformance tests were added in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/gpuweb/cts/pull/4516">https://github.com/gpuweb/cts/pull/4516</a>
Flag name on about://flags Enable Unsafe WebGPU
Finch feature name UnsafeWGSLFeatures
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/454653380">https://crbug.com/454653380</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 145
Shipping on Android 145
Shipping on WebView 145
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). No information provided

entry.title: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Overscroll effect on non-root scrollers
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Overscroll effect on non-root scrollers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Web%5C-Facing+Change+PSA%5C%3A+Overscroll+effect+on+non%5C-root+scrollers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Overscroll effect on non-root scrollers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251219" rel="nofollow">Fri, 19 Dec 2025 13:46:24 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e3859186868786819186cdcdcda3848c8c848f86cd808c8e">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#overscroll-behavior-properties">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#overscroll-behavior-properties</a>
Summary Shows elastic overscroll effects on non-root scroll containers. When a nested scrollable element reaches its scroll boundary, the overscroll affordance applies to that element instead of only the root scroller. This reduces the need for custom Javascript workarounds and can be controlled per element with overscroll-behavior.
Blink component Blink>Scroll
Web Feature ID No information provided
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility This feature is not developer-observable and presents no compatibility risk. Firefox and Safari already ship elastic overscroll effects for non-root scroll containers.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? No information provided
Debuggability No information provided
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes Only platforms with an overscroll effect will get one on non-root scrollers.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41102897">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41102897</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 144
Shipping on Android 144

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Performance+%5C%2B+Event+Timing%5C%3A+InteractionCount%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:41:30 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="264b4b4908080866414949414a430845494b">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a>
Design docs No information provided <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count</a>
Summary The Event Timing API is part of the Performance Timeline and is used to measure the performance of user interactions. Certain Events will have an interactionId value assigned to them, and this is useful for grouping related interactions based on common physical user inputs or gestures. This feature adds a very trivial performance.interactionCount, which is just the total number of interactions that have occured on the page. In particular, this feature is useful for computing the Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric value, which requires knowing the total number of interactions in order to compute a high percentile score (p98 for pages with greater than 50 total interactions). This feature has been specced for a long while, was prototypes in Chromium a long time ago but never shipped, is part of Interop 2025, and is already available in other browsers. (Note: there is already a more powerful performance.eventCounts map for specific events, but it is not possible to accurately map event cunts to interaction counts.)
Blink component Blink>PerformanceAPIs
Web Feature ID event-timing
Motivation Used to count the number of important real user interactions with a page. This is distinct from counting the number of events that Event Timing measures (because a single physical user gesture may fire many, variable number, of specific events, depending on the type of input and event target and page design) but you can already count interactions (inconveniently) by just counting the number of unique interactionId values in Event Timing API. Used for calculating Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric.
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Other browser venders have already shipped this feature as part of the Interop 2025 effort for CWV INP. The main interop risk is that there are existing polyfills for interactionCount in Chromium for INP calculation. However, popular polyfills (such as web-vitals.js) have long been tested to feature detect, given the long experimental web platform implementation in chromium.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069">https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069</a>)
WebKit: In development (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361</a>)
Web developers: Strongly positive No specific link, but this feature is related to the very popular INP metric definition (and obviates the need for an imperfect polyfill for counting interactions).
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? n/a
Debuggability DevTools has existing support for Interactions (real time performance monitor and tracing). Visualizing total interactionCount is not needed, but can be easily found (via literally counting the list of interactions, or just console logs).
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/">https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/</a> (several tests, look for interaction-count-*)
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name EventTimingInteractionCount
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Availability expectation Feature is available on Web Platform Baseline within 12 months of launch in Chrome (as part of Interop 2025 for INP)
Adoption expectation Polyfill already widely adopted (for INP calculation), and feature detection already used.
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 143
DevTrial on desktop 111
Shipping on Android 143
DevTrial on Android 111
Shipping on WebView 143
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). Already specced in Event Timing API.

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+ship%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+resources%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:49:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks for pointing out Mozilla's response. I think they have some fair </tt><tt>points. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>If we look at the list, it is clear from domain names, that some sites, </tt><tt>or entities, will benefit more from others from faster first-loads. I </tt><tt>mean, something like 30% of the list are from Google entities, from very </tt><tt>harmless (IMHO) hosted fonts to analytics, ads and video hosting </tt><tt>(YouTube). Some other big sites like Shopify and Wix/parastorage combine </tt><tt>to another 15%. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Having your key resources on that list may not matter very much, or it </tt><tt>may. The existence of the list is scary and I lack the data to </tt><tt>understand what the pros are both in scale and area. Is the disk space </tt><tt>issue a real problem or just something that is a potential concern </tt><tt>lacking investigation, for instance? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I understand that the published list is not a final, set-in-stone, item, </tt><tt>so I will not comment on individual items, but what thought have there </tt><tt>been on maintaining such a list long term? It seems to me that it might </tt><tt>become an area of contention that would be nice to avoid. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>In the initial intent, the claim was that this is important for the </tt><tt>healthy operation of the web. But is it really? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-10-22 15:43, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>FYI, I updated Chromestatus with Mozilla's position on the feature </tt><tt>(strongly negative). It's not a platform-exposed feature but they do </tt><tt>have concerns that they wanted to note in a position issue </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231</a>>. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Sat, Oct 18, 2025 at 8:34 AM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="25554840400b0b0b65464d574a484c50480b4a5742">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Sorry, I missed a step in making the candidate resource list public. I have moved it to my chromium account and made it public here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing</a>>.
Not everything in that list meets all of the criteria - it's just the first step in the manual curation (same URL served the same content across > 20k sites in the HTTP Archive dataset).
The manual steps frome there for meeting the criteria are basically:
- Cull the list for scripts, stylesheets and compression dictionaries. - Remove any URLs that use query parameters. - Exclude any responses that set cookies. - Identify URLs that are not manually versioned by site embedders (i.e. the embedded resource can not get stale). This is either in-place updating resources or automatically versioned resources. - Only include URLs that can reliably target a single resource by pattern (i.e. ..../<hash>-common.js but not ..../<hash>.js) - Get confirmation from the resource owner that the given URL Pattern is and will continue to be appropriate for the single-keyed cache
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 7:02 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e6e737b7b3030305e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Assuming we have the privacy and security concerns under control (which we're pretty confident is the case for the extremely small subset of resources we are talking about), the main discussion point is the balancing of incentives and "playing favorites".
As you noted, the performance impact is relatively small but it's not non-zero when you get to the scale of some of the resources we are talking about (like <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js">https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js</a> which is on 10M of the pages in the 50M page HTTP Archive dataset). This isn't really a framework discussion because those kinds of resources aren't a good fit for the restrictions that are in place for the privacy and security protections but there is a discussion about providing network benefits to specific third-parties that cross the pervasive threshold and meet the rest of the conditions (for at least part of the library).
The question is if the marginal performance benefit that can only be realized at that level of scale (where a given user would be likely to have the current version of that specific library in cache) would be a meaningful competitive factor for a newcomer (vs features, ease of use, pricing, mindshare, etc).
That also gets balanced against the user benefit of not having to keep re-downloading the exact same thing and from having to keep dozens of copies of it in cache, cached with different cache keys (taking cache space away from other resources).
There's also a more nuanced benefit that allows for federation of a feature across domains vs centralizing the experience. For example, Shopify and Wix's platform libraries show up in the candidate list as they are used by hundreds of thousands of sites in the CrUX dataset. Having a shared cache for those libraries would put them into a more competitive position against centralized platforms (Amazon, Etsy, Blogger, etc) while still allowing sites to own the overall experience.
I guess that's the long way of saying "it's complicated but we feel pretty strongly that the theoretical risk in this case is more than offset by the platform benefits".
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 5:15 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ea9a878f8fc4c4c4aa8982988587839f87c485988d">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Nothing is being pre-populated (other than the list of URL patterns). When a "pervasive" resource is encountered naturally by a given user, it will be stored in a single-keyed cache instead of a site/frame/url-keyed cache (reducing storage duplication for that specific resource for that specific user).
The linked doc has all of the mitigations in place, but the big one for explicit tracking is that it can only be used when full cookie access is also allowed, otherwise it falls through to the fully-partitioned cache.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:58 PM Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="12617e7b757a667e6b3c3c3c52717a607d7f7b677f3c7d6075">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
This is interesting, given all of the problems involved in governance and the way it cuts against platform progress <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/">https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/</a>>. Will the full set be downloaded before any pre-population is used? What controls will be in place to make sure that this does not exacerbate cross-site tracking via timing? Will these caches be pushed in a versioned way? Who will make the call about how much can be in the set? And are these delivered via component-updater?
Best,
Alex
On Friday, October 17, 2025 at 1:44:19 PM UTC-7 Patrick Meenan wrote:
I expect it will change over time but the changes should be pretty minor (as new resources increase or decrease popularity). Generally we'd want to include resources that have been common for a while and are likely to continue to be common. I'd expect small changes every milestone (or two). There's also the <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4c3c293e3a2d3f253a29612f2d6262620c2f243e232125392162233e2b">[email protected]</a> mailing list that you can ping to give us a heads-up (or a CL to Chromium) if there's something specific you want to draw attention to.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:33 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="483f29262c2d3a3e66666608252d3c29662b2725">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Thank you. Do you expect the list of resources to change over time? Will http archive data be analyzed for every milestone release?
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6f1f020a0a4141412f0c071d0002061a0241001d08">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 4:30 PM *To: *Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cabdaba4aeafb8bce4e4e48aa7afbeabe4a9a5a7">[email protected]</a>> *Cc: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e7c72777075337a7b685e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender Yes. The list will be committed directly to the Chromium repository. The list of candidate resources (before the manual vetting) is in a sheet here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$</a>>.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:15 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="89fee8e7edecfbffa7a7a7c9e4ecfde8a7eae6e4">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Will the list of manually curated scripts be published somewhere? I did not immediately see something like this skimming the doc or chrome status entry.
Thanks.
Ben
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d2a2bfb7b7fcfcfc92b1baa0bdbfbba7bffcbda0b5">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 3:12 PM *To: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c5a7a9acabaee8a1a0b385a6adb7aaa8acb0a8ebaab7a2">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *[blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender *Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6c1c0109094242422c0f041e030105190142031e0b">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* /N/A/
*Design docs*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$</a>>
*Summary* For a small number (hundreds) of hand-curated static third-party script, stylesheet and compression-dictionary resources that are used on a large portion of the web, Chrome will use a single-keyed HTTP cache to store those resources.
This helps users and site owners with faster performance for those resources that are very widely used while maintaining the privacy protections of the partitioned disk cache. This feature targets the resources that most users are likely to see multiple times across multiple sites in any given browsing session. They are usually not in the critical path of the page loading and may not impact the common performance metrics but they are still important for the healthy operation of the web.
The list of candidate resources is manually curated from the HTTP Archive dataset and updated on an ongoing basis. This includes site-independent things like common analytics scripts, social media embeds, video player embeds, captcha providers and ads libraries.
It allows for code that uses versioned URLs as long as the versioning is not a manual process by embedders and that the same version is sent to everybody at a given point in time with the same contents. This does not include things like common Javascript libraries where they are commonly self-hosted or where the URL references a specific version of the library and it is up to site owners to manually select a version.
i.e.
Yes:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js">https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJgSqmyqgQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJgSqmyqgQ$</a>> No:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js">https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJj4u2iLCA$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJj4u2iLCA$</a>>
*Blink component* Blink>Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:*22Blink*3ENetwork*22__;JSUl!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhr_KK6BQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:*22Blink*3ENetwork*22__;JSUl!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhr_KK6BQ$</a>>
*Web Feature ID* /No information provided/
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* This change is internal to Chrome and should be completely transparent to the web platform with no interoperability risks.
/Gecko/: N/A
/WebKit/: N/A
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
*Ergonomics* N/A
*Activation* N/A
*Security* Cache partitioning added a level of privacy protection that is being disabled for a small number of resources where it is deemed safe to do so. The linked document and issue provide the details on the protections that are in place to minimize the privacy exposure.
*WebView application risks*
/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?/
/No/
*Debuggability* N/A
