entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Attribution Reporting API
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Attribution Reporting API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Deprecate+and+Remove%5C%3A+Attribution+Reporting+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Attribution Reporting API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251112" rel="nofollow">Wed, 12 Nov 2025 08:44:50 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 for deprecation (not for the actual removal)
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-11-12 17:28, Vladimir Levin wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>LGTM1 to deprecate. This feature removal sounds riskier than other </tt><tt>related features, especially coupled with 20% page loads. So although </tt><tt>the plan to monitor for 6 milestones sounds good, this approval does </tt><tt>*not* extend to removal. Please come back to this thread closer to the </tt><tt>proposed removal to see if the usage had dropped substantially. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Sunday, November 9, 2025 at 7:47:04 PM UTC-5 Mike Taylor wrote:
Could you please request Debuggability and Testing bits in your chromestatus entry
On 11/8/25 3:35 a.m., Nan Lin wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Attribution Reporting API
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5b3732357575751b3833293436322e367534293c">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#016d686f2f2f2f416269736e6c68746c2f6e7366">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3b5752551515157b5853495456524e561554495c">[email protected]</span></a>>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a4cecfc5d68a8a8ae4c7ccd6cbc9cdd1c98acbd6c3">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#bdd7d6dccf939393fdded5cfd2d0d4c8d093d2cfda">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="781213190a565656381b100a1715110d1556170a1f">[email protected]</span></a>>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="593829382a3c352d30777777193a312b3634302c3477362b3e">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#f091809183959c8499dededeb09398829f9d99859dde9f8297">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1c7d6c7d6f797068753232325c7f746e737175697132736e7b">[email protected]</span></a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/attribution-reporting-api">https://github.com/WICG/attribution-reporting-api</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/attribution-reporting-api">https://github.com/WICG/attribution-reporting-api</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/">https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/">https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/</a>>
Summary
The Attribution Reporting API (ARA) is a privacy-preserving web API designed to measure ad conversions without third-party cookies or user tracking across sites.
Following Chrome's announcement <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/</a>>that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained, we are now planning to deprecate and remove
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>the Attribution Reporting API (along with certain other Privacy Sandbox APIs, as outlined on the Privacy Sandbox feature status page <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>).
Blink component
Internals > AttributionReporting
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Internals%3EAttributionReporting">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Internals%3EAttributionReporting</a>>
Web Feature ID
None
Motivation
Chrome has announced
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained. Given this, we expect adoption of the Attribution Reporting API to decrease over time, as cross-site measurement will remain possible in Chrome using third-party cookies. Further, although Microsoft Edge integrates with the Attribution Reporting API, most other browser engines have not signaled interest in launching the API. Removing this (and certain other Privacy Sandbox APIs <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>) will help focus efforts on the proposed interoperable Attribution <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/attribution">https://github.com/w3c/attribution</a>>standard.
Developer-facing impact
Sites that are using the Attribution Reporting API for conversion measurement and do not migrate to alternative solutions may experience a disruption in conversion measurement on eventual removal of the API code from Chrome.
*
Conversion measurement disruption:All ad conversion events relying on the deprecated API will fail to register or report. Sites using this API as their primary or supplementary method for ad measurement will lose visibility into campaign performance metrics derived from this technology.
*
Public API surface:The following outlines the consequences of deprecating and removing the Attribution Reporting API for each of the interfaces defined here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/#idl-index">https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/#idl-index</a>>.
o
Potentially user-breaking
+
XMLHttpRequest.setAttributionReporting(): Calling setAttributionReporting()on an XMLHttpRequestobject will throw an exception because the method will no longer exist. This is a breaking change for any site that calls this method. Given that this feature is not implemented in other browsers, it is likely that sites are already using feature detection to check the method’s existence before calling it, which would prevent breakage. We will start to track the usage of this method.
o
Non user-breaking
+
HTMLAttributionSrcElementUtilsand the attributionsrcattribute: The attributionsrcattribute on <a>, <area>, <img>, and <script> elements will be ignored. Any values assigned to this attribute will have no effect, and the browser will no longer initiate background requests to register attribution sources/triggers. Additionally we will no longer process trigger headers on legacy subresource requests that lack the opt-in (either on an element or fetch/XHR). This will not cause any visible breakage or errors on the page for the user, but it will silently prevent conversion measurement for sites that rely on this attribute.
+
attributionsrcin window.open(): The attributionsrcfeature in the featuresstring of a window.open()call will be ignored. The window will still open as requested, but no attribution source will be registered. This will not cause any visible breakage or errors on the pages for the user, but it will silently prevent conversion measurement for sites that rely on this functionality.
+
AttributionReportingRequestOptionsand the attributionReportingmember in RequestInit: The attributionReportingproperty within the options of a fetch() call will be ignored. The fetch request will still be made, but it will not trigger any attribution-related functionality. This change will not cause any JavaScript errors, but conversion measurement that relies on the fetch requests will no longer work.
+
Attribution-Reporting-Eligibleand Attribution-Reporting-Supportheaders: Since the browser will no longer process the attributionsrcattribute or the attributionReportingproperty in requests, it will no longer send these two headers on outgoing requests.
+
attribution-reportingpermission policy: Theattribution-reportingpermission policy
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/#permission-policy-integration">https://wicg.github.io/attribution-reporting-api/#permission-policy-integration</a>>will be removed along with the API. Since the API it controls will no longer exist, the permission policy will have no effect and its removal is not considered a breaking change.
Planning and Estimated Milestones
Deprecate the browser API surface in M144 and remove in M150.
There will be one aspect of ARA that will end sooner. Server-side summary report computation will no longer operate by late December 2025. We have already communicated to the users of that service of these plans. Such users can use debug reports instead until the removal of the ARA surface as a whole. Since this impacts post-facto server-side operations, it will not incur any user-facing breakage.
Currently ~20% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/webfeature/timeline/popularity/282">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/webfeature/timeline/popularity/282</a>>of page loads use the Attribution Reporting API. While ARA’s usage as a percentage of page loads is quite high, it is driven by a small number of third-party ad tech scripts present on a large number of sites. We will continue to monitor usage in addition to providing comprehensive updates on privacysandbox.google.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/">https://privacysandbox.google.com/</a>>with the status of the API and deprecation plans <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>.
We will proactively work toward reducing ARA usage to low levels once this intent is approved, including disallowing any new enrollment sign-ups, and contacting enrolled sites to inform them about the deprecation timelines.

To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/beb44d6a-aae5-4664-994a-38fb93bb4580n%40chromium.org">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/beb44d6a-aae5-4664-994a-38fb93bb4580n%40chromium.org</a>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent To Deprecate and Remove: Shared Storage API
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent To Deprecate and Remove: Shared Storage API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+To+Deprecate+and+Remove%5C%3A+Shared+Storage+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent To Deprecate and Remove: Shared Storage API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251112" rel="nofollow">Wed, 12 Nov 2025 08:43:26 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Part of the reason that I think that we can remove the other "privacy </tt><tt>sandbox" features so aggressively despite high usage numbers, is that </tt><tt>the number of actual users is very limited. I don't have the </tt><tt>understanding necessary to say if that is true for this one as well. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Or in other words, do you know how realistic it is to drive this to a </tt><tt>really, really, minute usage number through a deprecation? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>I am also more worried about the effect of breaking this compared to </tt><tt>some of the others. It seems more likely to actually cause site </tt><tt>breakage, if (I don't know this) it is used more widely than the other APIs. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Do you know more about those concerns?
/Daniel
On 2025-11-07 20:32, Cammie Smith Barnes wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Intent to deprecate and remove Shared Storage
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b1d2d0dc9f9f9ff1d2d9c3dedcd8c4dc9fdec3d6">[email protected]</a>
Explainer
</pre><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Specification
</pre><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/shared-storage/">https://wicg.github.io/shared-storage/</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/shared-storage/">https://wicg.github.io/shared-storage/</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Summary
</pre><tt>The Shared Storage API is a privacy-preserving web API to enable </tt><tt>storage that is not partitioned by first-party site. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Following Chrome's announcement </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/</a>>that the </tt><tt>current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained, we are now </tt><tt>planning to deprecate and remove the Shared Storage API (along with </tt><tt>certain other Privacy Sandbox APIs, as outlined on the Privacy Sandbox </tt><tt>feature status page <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Interest in the Shared Storage API has decreased since the </tt><tt>announcement. Use of sharedStorage.worklet.addModule() </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4264">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4264</a>>has </tt><tt>decreased ~20% from its peak of 7.35% of page loads down to 5.85% of </tt><tt>page loads. Use of sharedStorage.createWorklet() </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4836">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4836</a>>has </tt><tt>decreased ~82% from 4.87% to 0.864% of page loads. Use of </tt><tt>sharedStorage.run() </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4270">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4270</a>>has </tt><tt>decreased ~30% from 5.28% to 3.71% of page loads. Use of </tt><tt>sharedStorage.selectURL() </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4269">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4269</a>>has </tt><tt>decreased ~28% from 6.24% to 4.51% of page loads. Use of sharedStorage </tt><tt>overall </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263</a>>has </tt><tt>decreased ~9% from 11.91% of page loads to 10.86% of page loads. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Blink component
</pre><tt>Blink>Storage>SharedStorage </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EStorage%3ESharedStorage%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EStorage%3ESharedStorage%22</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Web Feature ID
None
Motivation
</pre><tt>Chrome has announced </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>that </tt><tt>the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained. Given </tt><tt>this, we expect adoption to decrease over time (currently at ~11% </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263</a>>of </tt><tt>page loads) as the main use cases for Shared Storage will remain </tt><tt>possible in Chrome using third-party cookies. Further, other browser </tt><tt>engines have not signaled interest in launching the API. See also the </tt><tt>initial public proposal below. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Developer-facing impact
</pre><tt>Sites that are using the Shared Storage API that do not migrate to </tt><tt>alternative solutions may experience a disruption in functionality, </tt><tt>and in particular all writes, reads, and worklet operations will fail. </tt><tt>If continued usage numbers warrant, we will take steps to minimize any </tt><tt>risk of actual page breakage, e.g. by temporarily retaining stub </tt><tt>implementations of the window-exposed methods that are still being </tt><tt>called most frequently. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
The following API surfaces will be removed:
*
All of the Shared Storage JavaScript functions exposed to the Window
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md#outside-of-worklets-eg-places-where-writing-can-happen">https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md#outside-of-worklets-eg-places-where-writing-can-happen</a>>will be removed or replaced with stub implementations:
o
`window.sharedStorage.worklet.addModule()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.createWorklet()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.worklet.run()`/`sharedStorage.run()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.worklet.selectURL()`/`sharedStorage.selectURL()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.set()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.append()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.delete()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.clear()`
o
`window.sharedStorage.batchUpdate()`
*
All of the Shared Storage JavaScript functions exposed only to the SharedStorageWorklet
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md#in-the-worklet-during-an-operation">https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage/blob/main/README.md#in-the-worklet-during-an-operation</a>>will be removed. Since the worklet operation methods (`sharedStorage.run()` and `sharedStorage.selectURL()` listed above) will be removed or replaced with no-op stub implementations, there will be no calls to any SharedStorageWorklet-exposed Shared Storage JavaScript functions, and so removing them will cause no breakage.
*
The SharedStorageWorklet interface will be removed or replaced by a stub worklet interface (potentially for `addModule`, `run`, `selectURL` stub implementations).
*
Consequently the `sharedStorage.worklet` attribute will either be removed or updated to the stub worklet interface type pending removal.
*
The `sharedStorage.context` attribute will be removed, along with the related `setSharedStorageContext()` method on fenced frame configs. We will measure the usage of `setSharedStorageContext()` to determine whether it should be replaced with a no-op stub implementation instead.
*
The `sharedstoragewritable` attribute on <iframe> and <img> elements will be ignored.
*
The `sharedStorageWritable` option in the fetch() API's RequestInit will be a no-op.
*
Consequently, the `Sec-Shared-Storage-Writable` and `Sec-Shared-Storage-Data-Origin` request headers will no longer be sent, and the `Shared-Storage-Write` and `Shared-Storage-Cross-Origin-Worklet-Allowed` response headers will no longer be honored.
*
The “shared-storage” and “shared-storage-select-url” permissions policy-controlled features will be removed along with the APIs. Since the APIs they control will no longer exist, the permission policies will have no effect and their removal is not considered a breaking change.
*
The `sharedStorage` attribute on the Window will be removed once all stub implementations are no longer needed and are removed.
Estimated milestones
Planning to deprecate in M144 and remove in M150.
</pre><tt>Currently, ~11% </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4263</a>>of </tt><tt>page loads use Shared Storage API. While this usage is quite high for </tt><tt>a deprecation and removal, it is driven by a small number of </tt><tt>third-party ad tech scripts present on a large number of sites. We </tt><tt>will continue to monitor usage in addition to providing comprehensive </tt><tt>updates on privacysandbox.google.com </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/">https://privacysandbox.google.com/</a>>with the status of the API and </tt><tt>deprecation plans <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>We will proactively work toward reducing usage to low levels once this </tt><tt>intent is approved, including disallowing any new enrollment sign-ups, </tt><tt>and contacting enrolled sites to inform them about the deprecation </tt><tt>timelines. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
</pre><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5076349064708096">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5076349064708096</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5076349064708096">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5076349064708096</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
-- </pre><tt>You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google </tt><tt>Groups "blink-dev" group. </tt><tt>To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send </tt><tt>an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5e3c32373035733a3b28752b302d2b3c2d3d2c7070701e3d362c3133372b3370312c39">[email protected]</a>. </tt><tt>To view this discussion visit </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJ8xcq6ty%3DiW_L9%3DpbzJbZKAT7rVdu_%2B9-QJ2P2ojCRtSRk4xw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJ8xcq6ty%3DiW_L9%3DpbzJbZKAT7rVdu_%2B9-QJ2P2ojCRtSRk4xw%40mail.gmail.com</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJ8xcq6ty%3DiW_L9%3DpbzJbZKAT7rVdu_%2B9-QJ2P2ojCRtSRk4xw%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJ8xcq6ty%3DiW_L9%3DpbzJbZKAT7rVdu_%2B9-QJ2P2ojCRtSRk4xw%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>. </tt></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;">

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Protected Audience
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Protected Audience
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Deprecate+and+Remove%5C%3A+Protected+Audience%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Protected Audience</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251112" rel="nofollow">Wed, 12 Nov 2025 08:36:52 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-11-12 17:30, Vladimir Levin wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
</pre><tt>On Wednesday, November 12, 2025 at 11:30:32 AM UTC-5 Chris Harrelson </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM1
On Fri, Nov 7, 2025 at 11:04 AM Paul Jensen <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="364657435a5c535818181876555e44595b5f435b18594451">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Protected Audience
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2858495d44424d46060606684b405a4745415d4506475a4f">[email protected]</a>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/FLEDGE.md">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/FLEDGE.md</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/FLEDGE.md">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/FLEDGE.md</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/">https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/">https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/</a>>
Summary
The Protected Audience API provides a method of interest-group advertising without third-party cookies or user tracking across sites.
Following Chrome's announcement <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/privacy-sandbox-next-steps/</a>>that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained, we are now planning to deprecate and remove
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>the Protected Audience API (along with certain other Privacy Sandbox APIs, as outlined on the Privacy Sandbox feature status page <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>).
Blink component
Blink>InterestGroups
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EInterestGroups%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EInterestGroups%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
None
Motivation
Chrome has announced that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained. Since that announcement there has been virtually no interest in the Protected Audience API. Use of the joinAdInterestGroup() API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/3855">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/3855</a>>has decreased by almost 100x and use of the runAdAuction() API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/3857">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/3857</a>>has decreased by more than 10x. Of the auctions occurring today, virtually none of them have winners (determined by looking at the “Success” bucket count of the Ads.InterestGroup.Auction.Result UMA), implying that they are not providing useful benefit to the pages initiating them.
Initial public proposal
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>.
Developer-facing impact
Given that virtually none of the Protected Audience auctions occurring today have winners, we estimate the lost utility from this removal to be negligible.
User-facing risks
The user-facing risks are small. While removing the JavaScript API could cause pages to break, the impact should be limited to sites that don't employ standard defensive coding or feature detection, which should be rare since not all browsers implement the API.
If usage warrants, we will take steps to avoid any risk of page breakage, e.g. by temporarily retaining a stub implementation of Navigator APIs joinAdInterestGroup(), runAdAuction(), leaveAdInterestGroup(), clearOriginJoinedAdInterestGroups(), getInterestGroupAdAuctionData(), canLoadAdAuctionFencedFrame(), createAuctionNonce(), updateAdInterestGroups(), protectedAudience.queryFeatureSupport(), deprecatedReplaceInURN(), deprecatedURNtoURL(), and adAuctionComponents() that mimic current behavior when a user has disabled Protected Audience.
Estimated milestones
Planning to deprecate in M144 and remove in M150.
Currently 0.22% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4188">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4188</a>>of page loads use the Protected Audience API. These are driven by a small number of third-party ad tech scripts present on a large number of sites. We will continue to monitor usage as well as provide comprehensive updates on privacysandbox.google.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/">https://privacysandbox.google.com/</a>>with the status of the API and deprecation plans <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status">https://privacysandbox.google.com/overview/status</a>>.
We will also proactively work toward reducing usage to low levels once this intent is approved, including disallowing any new enrollment sign-ups, and contacting enrolled sites to inform them about the deprecation timelines.
Protected Audience features that were never launched beyond 20% Stable (TextEncoder support <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/961#issuecomment-2793763963">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/961#issuecomment-2793763963</a>>, Creative scanning via BYOS/V1 trusted scoring signals
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/EXfp34Qb1oc/m/oaiY6MENBwAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/EXfp34Qb1oc/m/oaiY6MENBwAJ</a>>, Selectable Reporting IDs
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/1cWqBPHngd0/m/gSYeR_dPAAAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/1cWqBPHngd0/m/gSYeR_dPAAAJ</a>>) will be ramped down by the end of 2025.
Protected Audience services, Bidding and Auction services
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/CyXJz3xOEcc/m/1snkv2KhAwAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/CyXJz3xOEcc/m/1snkv2KhAwAJ</a>>and Trusted Key Value service
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/fH8u7ZTNZg8/m/oo0WVw7SAQAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/fH8u7ZTNZg8/m/oo0WVw7SAQAJ</a>>, will not onboard new clients once deprecation is approved. We will work with onboarded clients and plan to turn down the services by the end of year as usage is negligible today. This will have no user-facing or web-compat impact.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6552486106234880">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6552486106234880</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6552486106234880">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6552486106234880</a>>
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CABQTWrnevtY14OMos%2BuDgzXtFwQJ5vzY3hEMmyRFQBKDHBz-9A%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CABQTWrnevtY14OMos%2BuDgzXtFwQJ5vzY3hEMmyRFQBKDHBz-9A%40mail.gmail.com</a>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Topics API
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Topics API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Deprecate+and+Remove%5C%3A+Topics+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Topics API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251112" rel="nofollow">Wed, 12 Nov 2025 08:35:36 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3 according to Vlad's plan.
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-11-12 17:19, Chris Harrelson wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 with the same conditions Vlad mentioned.
</pre><tt>On Wed, Nov 12, 2025 at 8:16 AM Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="96e0fbe6b8b8b8d6f5fee4f9fbffe3fbb8f9e4f1">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM1 to deprecate. The plan to keep deprecation for 6 milestones also sounds good. Please come back after to this thread at a time when you think the removal can proceed. Since the amount of page loads is extremely high, we would like to reserve the right to pause the removal if this amount of page loads does not decrease substantially.
On Friday, November 7, 2025 at 1:12:36 PM UTC-5 Yao Xiao wrote:
Intent to Deprecate and Remove: Topics API
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="552c343a7b7b7b15363d273a383c20387b3a2732">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#2158404e0f0f0f614249534e4c48544c0f4e5346">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e29b838dcccccca2818a908d8f8b978fcc8d9085">[email protected]</span></a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/topics">https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/topics</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/topics">https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/topics</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://patcg-individual-drafts.github.io/topics/">https://patcg-individual-drafts.github.io/topics/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://patcg-individual-drafts.github.io/topics/">https://patcg-individual-drafts.github.io/topics/</a>>
Summary
The Topics API is a privacy-preserving web API to enable ad-targeting based on a person’s general browsing interests, without exposing their exact browsing history.
Following Chrome's announcement that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained, we are now planning to deprecate and remove the Topics API (along with other Privacy Sandbox APIs).
The following API surfaces will be affected:
*
The JavaScript function `document.browsingTopics()` will be removed.
*
The `browsingtopics` attribute on <iframe> and <img> elements will be ignored.
*
The `browsingTopics` option in the fetch() API's RequestInit will be a no-op.
*
Consequently, the `Sec-Browsing-Topics` request header will no longer be sent, and the `Observe-Browsing-Topics` response header will no longer be honored.
*
The "browsing-topics" and "interest-cohort" permissions policy features will be removed.
Blink component
Blink>TopicsAPI
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ETopicsAPI%22">https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ETopicsAPI%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
None
Motivation
Chrome has announced that the current approach to third-party cookies will be maintained. Given this, we expect adoption to decrease over time (currently at 13% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5102">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5102</a>>of page loads) as interest based advertising will remain possible in Chrome using third-party cookies. Further, other browser engines have not signaled interest in launching the API. See also the initial public proposal below.
Initial public proposal
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/">https://privacysandbox.com/news/update-on-plans-for-privacy-sandbox-technologies/</a>>.
Possible breakage
Sites that rely on Topics API for targeting will experience utility impact.
If usage warrants, we will take steps to avoid any risk of page breakage, e.g. by temporarily retaining a stub implementation of `document.browsingTopics()` that mimics current behavior when a user has no topics to return. However, since Topics is not enabled by default for all users, sites should already be using feature detection, which makes the risks of breakage low.
Debuggability
N/A
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Estimated milestones
Deprecate in M144 and then remove in M150.
Currently, ~13% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5102">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5102</a>>of page loads use Topics API. These are driven by a small number of third-party ad tech scripts present on a large number of sites. We will continue to monitor usage as well as provide comprehensive updates on privacysandbox.google.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://goo.gle/ps-status">http://goo.gle/ps-status</a>>with the status of the API and deprecation plans.
We will also proactively work toward reducing usage to a low level once the intent is approved, including disallowing any new enrollment sign-ups, and contacting all enrolled sites that use the Privacy Sandbox APIs to inform them about the deprecation timelines.

entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Non-Tree-Scoped container-name Matching
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Non%5C-Tree%5C-Scoped+container%5C-name+Matching%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Non-Tree-Scoped container-name Matching</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251119" rel="nofollow">Wed, 19 Nov 2025 10:19:44 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 11/19/25 11:23 a.m., Chris Harrelson wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1</pre><pre></pre><tt>On Wed, Nov 19, 2025 at 7:03 AM Rune Lillesveen <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="660013120e48484826050e14090b0f130b48091401">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="335546475b1d1d1d73505b415c5e5a465e1d5c4154">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-conditional-5/#container-name">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-conditional-5/#container-name</a>
*Summary* Ignore tree-scope when matching container-name for @container queries.
Previously, container-name matching for container queries used tree-scoped names/references for matching, which meant the same name would not match if the @container rule and the container-type property were originating from different trees such that that container-type declaration came from an inner shadow tree.
With this change container names match regardless of @container rule or container-type declaration origins.
*Blink component* Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* Missing feature
*Motivation* Aligning with the spec change and Firefox implementation.
*Initial public proposal* /No information provided/
*TAG review* /No information provided/
*TAG review status* Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* The risk is that container-names set in shadow trees may now match as flat tree ancestor container for outer tree elements which are slotted into the shadow tree, or for ::part rules targeting elements inside the shadow tree which additionally rely on @container queries in outer tree rules.
M142 introduced a use counter along with the implementation for detecting such cases in the wild: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5659">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5659</a>
Three sites reported back:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://redhatofficial.github.io/:">https://redhatofficial.github.io/:</a> Sets padding which is overridden by another declaration not affected by container queries. No change.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.redhat.com/: Sets">https://www.redhat.com/: Sets</a> padding to 0, which is also the initial value. No change.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.kansascityfed.org/: Not">https://www.kansascityfed.org/: Not</a> able to trigger loading or navigating around this site.
Firefox has always shipped this behavior without noticing any interop issues according to the discussion in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12090#issuecomment-3204775586">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12090#issuecomment-3204775586</a>
/Gecko/: Shipped/Shipping Firefox shipped this behavior in their initial release of container queries.
/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping In Safari TP
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
/No information provided/
*Debuggability* /No information provided/
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-conditional/container-queries/container-for-shadow-dom.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-conditional/container-queries/container-for-shadow-dom.html</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-conditional/container-queries/container-units-shadow.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-conditional/container-queries/container-units-shadow.html</a>
*Flag name on about://flags* #experimental-web-platform-features
*Finch feature name* CSSContainerNameNotTreeScoped
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/440049800">https://crbug.com/440049800</a>
*Estimated milestones* Shipping on desktop 144 DevTrial on desktop 142 Shipping on Android 144 DevTrial on Android 142 Shipping on WebView 144
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
/No information provided/
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194034339512320?gate=4770497078362112">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194034339512320?gate=4770497078362112</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> Rune Lillesveen </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Groups "blink-dev" group. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CACuPfeSPHANJS4nmVo_LyvoA_XYJNnHqjp9tCE3A9UjhoNhJRQ%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CACuPfeSPHANJS4nmVo_LyvoA_XYJNnHqjp9tCE3A9UjhoNhJRQ%40mail.gmail.com</a>

entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+ship%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+resources%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251119" rel="nofollow">Wed, 19 Nov 2025 09:07:05 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>We had a discussion about this in the API OWNERS meeting and I was asked </tt><tt>to make my thoughts public. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
There are a couple of aspects to this:</pre><pre></pre><tt>1. This is trying to mitigate some negative effects of a </tt><tt>security/privacy enhancing change (triple keyed cache). The negative </tt><tt>effects are, as far as I can determine, in the form of reduced ad </tt><tt>revenue ("web ecosystem") because some ad network scripts will have to </tt><tt>be reloaded from servers. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>2. There is a fundamental idea that a browser should treat every </tt><tt>resource on the web equally (modulo security and some other exceptions). </tt><tt>This is violating that idea. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>3. The list of resources that will be allowed to bypass the third cache </tt><tt>key was created through a reasonably impartial method. Still, because </tt><tt>the web is what it is, that resulted in certain entities getting a lot </tt><tt>of their resources on the list. If I recall correctly, 30% of the list </tt><tt>was Google resources in one form or another. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>4. Every resource on the list opens up the potential for the </tt><tt>security/privacy issues that the triple keyed cache was meant to protect </tt><tt>against. Is there a point where the list has undermined enough of the </tt><tt>benefits that the whole triple keyed cache should be dropped instead? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>All of this, and more, has to be weighed against each other to get to a </tt><tt>solution with an "ideal" balance. I currently do not know what that </tt><tt>balance is. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I do not like the look of certain aspects here, but on the other hand I </tt><tt>do like the security/privacy improvements and it would be sad if those </tt><tt>have to be reverted because some considered them too costly. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>This post does not really change anything, but just so that you know </tt><tt>what is being voiced. And if someone has more to add, please do add your </tt><tt>own information and thoughts. Especially if I have misunderstood or </tt><tt>mischaracterized something. That is what these threads are for. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-11-09 16:46, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Sat, Nov 8, 2025 at 1:32 PM Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="354c5a544342501b1b1b75565d475a585c40581b5a4752">[email protected]</a>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
I'm extremely supportive of this effort, with multiple hats on.
I'd have loved if this wasn't restricted to users with 3P cookies enabled, but one can imagine abuse where pervasive resource *patterns* are used, but with unique hashes that are not deployed in the wild, and where each such URL is used as a cross-origin bit of entropy.
</pre><tt>Yep, there are 2 risks for explicit tracking (that are effectively </tt><tt>moot when you can track directly anyway). Differing the content of </tt><tt>some of the responses some of the time (maybe for a slightly different </tt><tt>URL than the "current" version that still matches the pattern) and </tt><tt>using a broad sample of not-current URLs across a bunch of origins as </tt><tt>a fingerprint. We can make some of that harder but I couldn't think of </tt><tt>any way to completely eliminate the risk. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Sat, Nov 8, 2025 at 7:04 AM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b3c3ded6d69d9d9df3d0dbc1dcdedac6de9ddcc1d4">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
The list construction should already be completely objective. I changed the manual origin-owner validation to trust and require "cache-control: public" instead. The rest of the criteria
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?tab=t.0">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?tab=t.0</a>> should be well-defined and objective. I'm not sure if they can be fully automated yet (though that might just be my pre-AI thinking).
The main need for humans in the loop right now is to create the patterns so that they each represent a "single" resource that is stable over time with URL changes (version/hash) and distinguishing those stable files from random hash bundles that aren't stable from release to release. That's fairly easy for a human to do (and get right).
This is something that origins that use compression dictionaries already do by themselves - define the "match" pattern that covers the URL's semantics. Can we somehow use that for automation where it exists?
</pre><tt>We can use the match patterns for script and style destinations as an </tt><tt>input when defining the patterns. If the resource URL matches the </tt><tt>match pattern and the match pattern is reasonably long (not /app/*.js) </tt><tt>then it's probably a good pattern (and could be validated across </tt><tt>months of HTTP Archive logs). There are patterns where dictionaries </tt><tt>aren't used as strict delta updates for the same file (i.e. a script </tt><tt>with a lot of common code that portions of which might be in other </tt><tt>scripts used on other pages) so I wouldn't want to use it blindly but </tt><tt>it is a very strong possibility. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Fri, Nov 7, 2025 at 4:47 PM Rick Byers <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="384a5a41161616785b504a5755514d5516574a5f">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Thanks Pat. I am personally a big fan of things which increase publisher ad revenue across the web broadly without hurting (or ideally improving) the user experience, and this seems likely to do exactly that. In particular I recall all the debate around stale-while-revalidate <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://web.dev/articles/stale-while-revalidate">https://web.dev/articles/stale-while-revalidate</a>> and am proud that we pushed
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/rspPrQHfFkI/m/c5j3xJQRDAAJ?e=48417069">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/rspPrQHfFkI/m/c5j3xJQRDAAJ?e=48417069</a>> through it with urgency and confirmed it indeed increased publisher ad revenue across the web
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://web.dev/case-studies/ads-case-study-stale-while-revalidate">https://web.dev/case-studies/ads-case-study-stale-while-revalidate</a>>.
Reading the Mozilla feedback carefully the point that resonates most with me is the risk of "gatekeeping" and the potential to mitigate that by establishing objective rules for inclusion. Is it plausible to imagine a version of this where the list construction would be entirely objective? What would the tradeoffs be?
Thanks, Rick
On Thu, Oct 30, 2025 at 3:50 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c2b2afa7a7ececec82a1aab0adafabb7afecadb0a5">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Reaching out to site owners was mostly for a sanity check that the resource is not expecting to be partitioned for some reason (even though the payloads are known to be identical). If it helps, we can replace the reach-out step with a requirement that the responses be "Cache-Control: public" (and hard-enforce it in the browser by not writing the resource to cache if it isn't). That is an explicit indicator that the resources are cacheable in shared upstream caches.
I removed the 2 items from the design doc that were specifically targeted at direct fingerprinting since that's moot with the 3PC link (as well as the fingerprinting bits from the validation with resource owners).
On the site-preferencing concern, it doesn't actually preference large sites but it does preference currently-popular third-party resources (most of which are provided by large corporations). The benefit is spread across all of the sites that they are embedded in (funnily enough, most large sites won't benefit because they don't tend to use third-parties).
Determining the common resources at a local level exposes the same XS Leak issues as allowing all resources (i.e. your local map tiles will show up in multiple cache partitions because they all reference your current location but they can be used to identify your location since they are not globally common). Instead of using the HTTP Archive to collect the candidates, we could presumably build a centralized list based on aggregated common resources that are seen across cache partitions by each user but that feels like an awful lot of complexity for a very small number of resulting resources.
On the test results, sorry, I thought I had included the experiment results in the I2S but it looks like I may not have.
The test was specifically just with the patterns for the Google ads scripts because we aren't expecting this feature to impact the vitals for the main page/content since most of the pervasive resources are third-party content that is usually async already and not critical-path. It's possible some video or map embeds might trigger LCP in some cases but that's the exception more than the norm. This is more geared to making those supporting things work better while maintaining the user experience. Ads has the kind of instrumentation that we'd need to be able to get visibility into the success (or failure) of that assumption and to be able to measure small changes.
The results were stat-sig positive but relatively small. The ad iframes displayed their content slightly faster and transmitted fewer bytes for each frame (very low single digit percentages).
The guardrail metrics, including vitals) were all neutral which is what we were hoping for (improvement without a cost of increased contention).
If you'd feel more comfortable with gathering more data, I wouldn't be opposed to running the full list at 1% to check the guardrail metrics again before fully launching. We won't necessarily expect to see positive movement to justify a launch since the resources are still async but we can validate that assumption with the full list at least (if that is the only remaining concern).
On Thu, Oct 30, 2025 at 5:28 PM Rick Byers <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0e7c6c772020204e6d667c6163677b6320617c69">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Thanks Erik and Patrick, of course that makes sense. Sorry for the naive question. My naive reading of the design doc suggested to me that a lot of the privacy mitigations were about preventing the cross-site tracking risk. Could the design be simplified by removing some of those mitigations? For example, the section about reaching out to the resource owners, to what extent is that really necessary when all we're trying to mitigate is XS leaks? Don't the popularity properties alone mitigate that sufficiently?
What can you share about the magnitude of the performance benefit in practice in your experiments? In particular for LCP, since we know <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpostats.com/">https://wpostats.com/</a>> that correlates well with user engagement (and against abandonment) and so presumably user value.
The concern about not wanting to further advantage more popular sites over less popular ones resonates with me. Part of that argument seems to apply broadly to the idea of any LRU cache (especially one with a reuse bias which I believe ours has
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/developers/design-documents/network-stack/disk-cache/#eviction">https://www.chromium.org/developers/design-documents/network-stack/disk-cache/#eviction</a>>?). But perhaps an important distinction here is that the benefits are determined globally vs. on a user-by-user basis? But I think any solution that worked on a user-by-user basis would have the XS leak problem, right? Perhaps it's worth reflecting on our stance on using crowd-sourced data to try to improve the experience for all users while still being fair to sites broadly. In general I think this is something Chromium is much more open to (where it brings significant user benefit) than other engines. For example, our Media Engagement Index <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/autoplay">https://developer.chrome.com/blog/autoplay</a>> system has some similar properties in terms of using aggregate user behaviour to help decide which sites have the power to play audio on page load and which don't. I was personally uncertain at the time if the complexity would prove to be worth the benefit, but now I'm quite convinced it is. Playing audio on load is just something users and developers want in a few cases, but not most cases. I wonder if perhaps cross-site caching is similar?
Rick
On Thu, Oct 30, 2025 at 9:09 AM Matt Menke <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7815151d565656381f17171f141d561b1715">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Note that even with Vary: Origin, we still have to load the HTTP request headers from the disk cache to apply the vary header, which leaks timing information, so "Vary: Origin" is not a sufficient security mechanism to prevent that sort of cross-site attack.
On Wednesday, October 29, 2025 at 5:08:42 PM UTC-4 Erik Anderson wrote:
My understanding was that there was believed to be a meaningful security benefit with partitioning the cache. That’s because it would limit a party from being able to inferr that you’ve visited some other site by measuring a side effect tied to how quickly a resource loads. That observation could potentially be made even if that specific adversary doesn’t have any of their own content loaded on the other site.
Of course, if there is an entity with a resource loaded across both sites with a 3p cookie /and/ they’re willing to share that info/collude, there’s not much benefit. And even when partitioned, if 3p cookies are enabled, there are potentially measurable side effects that differ based on if the resource request had some specific state in a 3p cookie.
Does that incremental security benefit of partitioning the cache justify the performance costs when 3p cookies are still enabled? I’m not sure.
Even if partitioning was eliminated, a site could protect themselves a bit by specifying Vary: Origin, but that probably doesn’t sufficiently cover iframe scenarios (nor would I expect most sites to hold it right).
*From:*Rick Byers <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6311011a4d4d4d23000b110c0e0a160e4d0c1104">[email protected]</a>> *Sent:* Wednesday, October 29, 2025 11:56 AM *To:* Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="06766b6328282846656e74696b6f736b28697461">[email protected]</a>> *Cc:* Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c2afaba9a7ececec82a1aab0adafabb7afecadb0a5">[email protected]</a>>; blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5b393732357575751b3833293436322e367534293c">[email protected]</a>> *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
If this is enabled only when 3PCs are enabled, then what are the tradeoffs of going through all this complexity and governance vs. just broadly coupling HTTP cache keying behavior to 3PC status in some way? What can a tracker credibly do with a single-keyed HTTP cache that they cannot do with 3PCs? Are there also concerns about accidental cross-site resource sharing which could be mitigated more simply by other means, eg. by scoping to just to ETag-based caching?
I remember the controversy and some real evidence of harm to users and businesses in 2020 when we partitioned the HTTP cache, but I was convinced that we had to accept that harm in order to credibly achieve 3PCD. At the time I was personally a fan of a proposal like this (even for users without 3PCs) in order to mitigate the harm. But now it seems to me that if we're going to start talking about poking holes in that decision, perhaps we should be doing a larger review of the options in that space with the knowledge that most Chrome users are likely to continue to have 3PCs enabled. WDYT?
Thanks,
Rick
On Mon, Oct 27, 2025 at 10:27 AM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7b0b161e5555553b1813091416120e165514091c">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
I don't believe the security/privacy protections actually rely on the assertions (and it's unlikely those would be public). It's more for awareness and to make sure they don't accidentally break something with their app if they were relying on the responses being partitioned by site.
As far as query params go, the browser code already only filters for requests with no query params so any that do rely on query params won't get included anyway.
The same goes for cookies. Since the feature is only enabled when third-party cookies are enabled, adding cookies to these responses or putting unique content in them won't actually pierce any new boundaries but it goes against the intent of only using it for public/static resources and they'd lose the benefit of the shared cache when it gets updated. Same goes for the fingerprinting risks if the pattern was abused.
On Mon, Oct 27, 2025 at 9:39 AM Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1b7672707e3535355b7873697476726e763574697c">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
On 10/22/25 5:48 p.m., Patrick Meenan wrote:
The candidate list goes down to 20k occurrences in order to catch resources that were updated mid-crawl and may have multiple entries with different hashes that add up to 100k+ occurrences. In the candidate list, without any filtering, the 100k cutoff is around 600, I'd estimate that well less than 25% of the candidates make it through the filtering for stable pattern, correct resource type and reliable pattern. First release will likely be 100-200 and I don't expect it will ever grow above 500.
Thanks - I see the living document has been updated to mention 500 as a ceiling.
As far as cadence goes, I expect there will be a lot of activity for the next few releases as individual patterns are coordinated with the origin owners but then it will settle down to a much more bursty pattern of updates every few Chrome releases (likely linked with an origin changing their application and adding more/different resources). And yes, it is manual.
As far as the process goes, resource owners need to actively assert that their resource is appropriate for the single-keyed cache and that they would like it included (usually in response to active outreach from us but we have the external-facing list for owner-initiated contact as well). The design doc has the documentation for what it means to be appropriate (and the doc will be moved to a readme page in the repository next to the actual list so it's not a hard-to-find Google doc):
Will there be any kind of public record of this assertion? What happens if a site starts using query params or sending cookies? Does the person in charge of manual list curation discover that in the next release? Does that require a new release (I don't know if this lives in component updater, or in the binary itself)?
*5. Require resource owner opt-in* For each URL to be included, reach out to the team/company responsible for the resource to validate the URL pattern and get assurances that the pattern will always serve the same content to all sites and not be abused for tracking (by using unique URLs within the pattern mask as a bit-mask for fingerprinting). They will also need to validate that the URLs covered by the pattern will not rely on being able to set cookies over HTTP using a Set-CookieHTTP response header because they will not be re-applied across cache boundaries (the set-cookie is not cached with the resource).
On Wed, Oct 22, 2025 at 5:31 PM Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="acc1c5c7c9828282eccfc4dec3c1c5d9c182c3decb">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
On 10/18/25 8:34 a.m., Patrick Meenan wrote:
Sorry, I missed a step in making the candidate resource list public. I have moved it to my chromium account and made it public here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing</a>>.
Not everything in that list meets all of the criteria - it's just the first step in the manual curation (same URL served the same content across > 20k sites in the HTTP Archive dataset).
The manual steps frome there for meeting the criteria are basically:
- Cull the list for scripts, stylesheets and compression dictionaries.
- Remove any URLs that use query parameters.
- Exclude any responses that set cookies.
- Identify URLs that are not manually versioned by site embedders (i.e. the embedded resource can not get stale). This is either in-place updating resources or automatically versioned resources.
- Only include URLs that can reliably target a single resource by pattern (i.e. ..../<hash>-common.js but not ..../<hash>.js)
- Get confirmation from the resource owner that the given URL Pattern is and will continue to be appropriate for the single-keyed cache
A few questions on list curation:
Can you clarify how big the list will be? The privacy review at
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5202380930678784?gate=5174931459145728 mentions">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5202380930678784?gate=5174931459145728 mentions</a> ~500, while the design doc mentions 1000. I see the candidate resource list starts at ~5000, then presumably manual curation begins to get to one of those numbers.
What is the expected list curation/update cadence? Is it actually manual?
Is there any recourse process for owners of resources that don't want to be included? Do we have documentation on what it mean to be appropriate for the single-keyed cache?
thanks, Mike

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Focus%27s+focusVisible+option%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Focus's focusVisible option</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251120" rel="nofollow">Thu, 20 Nov 2025 10:23:47 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ee8ac0c0c0ae8d869c8183879b83c0819c89">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-focusoptions-focusvisible">https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-focusoptions-focusvisible</a>
Summary When calling the `focus()` method, developers can supply a `focusVisible` boolean in the FocusOptions dictionary. When true, a focus ring will always be painted around the newly-focused element and it will match the `:focus-visible` pseudo-class. When false, the focus ring will not be painted and `:focus-visible` will not match. When missing, the user agent make its own determination as to whether the focus ring should be painted, and the :focus-visible pseudo-class matches accordingly.
Blink component Blink>HTML>Focus
Web Feature ID Missing feature
Motivation No information provided
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility No risks, the feature is opt-in and both WebKit and Gecko already ship this feature. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/html/interaction/focus/processing-model/focusVisible.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=html%2Finteraction%2Ffocus%2Fprocessing-model%2Ffocusvisible.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/html/interaction/focus/processing-model/focusVisible.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=html%2Finteraction%2Ffocus%2Fprocessing-model%2Ffocusvisible.html</a>
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8087">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8087</a>)
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8087">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8087</a>)
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? No information provided
Debuggability No information provided
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes
Flag name on about://flags No information provided

Non-finch justification Per <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/flag_guarding_guidelines.md#When-is-a-flag-not-required">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/flag_guarding_guidelines.md#When-is-a-flag-not-required</a>, this falls under the "Simple parameters change" exemption.

Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues.
